Media_Bias-T4J documentation
Media_Bias-T4J documentation

Welcome to Media_Bias-T4J’s documentation!¶

Too Much Information Preliminary Experiment¶

Main Dataframe Experiment¶

class t4jbias-backend.tmi.tmi_logic.TMIAnalysis(article_dictionary: dict)¶

This class contains multiple methods to perfrom an analysis in order to find out whether or not too much information is given about a specific subject. All methods can be invoked indepedently from each other and manipulate the class’s dataframe.

account_for_positively_biased(port: int = 9000) → None¶

The established bias from the function “is_biased_from_descriptor” automatically labels every headline having more than 2 descriptors as Negatively biased. However, there might be cases where a headline has more than 2 descriptors but is positively biased. To distinguish this case, a CoreNLP sentiment analysis is performed on any sentence containing more than 2 descriptors.

Parameters

port (int, optional) – Port the CoreNLP server is running on, defaults to 9000

article_length_mediatype_correlation(article_types: list) → list¶

Determine the relationship between the type of newspaper (print/online media and online only media) and the overall article length. The returned arguments can be used for plotting.

Parameters

article_types (list) – An ordered list of strings containing the type of news_outlet for the corresponding row. String is either “online” or “print”.

Returns

Returns three lists. 1: X-Axis Values 2: Standard error for online & print, 3: Averages of word length for online & print

Return type

Union[list, list, list]

descriptors_headline(port: int = 9000) → None¶

Adds the descriptor count and name as columns to dataframe. Classified as descriptor is any node left on an “NN” that is also a parent of the same “NP” node. Exceptions include english stopwords.

Parameters

port (int, optional) – Port the CoreNLP server is running on, defaults to 9000

extract_subject_object_action() → None¶

Extracting the subject, object and action from the headline using Watson NLP.

filter_out_articles(category: str) → None¶

Filter out all articles that are not recognised as the category string by Watson. Applicable categories can be found at: https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/natural-language-understanding?topic=natural-language-understanding-categories-hierarchy-v1 E.g. “/society/crime”

Parameters

category (str) – Category that should NOT be filtered out.

find_ethnicity_keywords() → None¶

Adds count of specific ethnic keywords in article text as a new column.

get_entities() → None¶

Get the entities in an article from Watson NLU.

get_img_caption_byline_excerpt(api_port: int = 8080) → None¶

Retrieves the image caption (if available), byline and excerpt from the article.

!Important!: NodeJS API needs to be started locally. (Located in “./readability-api”)

Parameters

api_port (int, optional) – Port the NodeJS API is running on, defaults to 8080

hedges_booster_factiveverbs() → None¶

Adds hedges, boosters and factive verb counts as individual columns to the dataframe.

is_biased_from_descriptor() → None¶

Determines whether or not headline is biased based from count of descriptors. Rules: < 2 descriptors -> Positive (not biased/TLI)

== 2 descriptors -> Neutral (not biased) > 2 descriptors -> Negative (biased / TMI)

is_subject_entity_person() → None¶

Is the subject mentioned in the headline an entitiy of type person? Determined using Watson NLP’s entities.

is_subject_in_headline() → None¶

Determines for each row whether a subject is present in the corresponding headline.

object_correspond_context(context: str) → None¶

Does the object in the headline equal the context of the headline? E.g. “Daycare Worker charged with murder after assaulting baby who wouldn’t nap, cops say” The object (murder) == context (murder) An object not corresponding to the context might be a sign of framing bias. E.g. the object is the age of the murderer.

Parameters

context (str) – The context for the analysis. Usually aligns with the keyword searched for with BingAPI.

object_subject_mention_imagecaptions() → None¶

Check whether the subject / object or both are mentioned in the headline. Adds new column with S = subject in headline, O = object in headline, S/O = Subject&Object in headline.

political_spectrum() → None¶

Determine the political spectrum of the specific newspaper outlet using information provided by the website “www.allsides.com”.

Helperfunctions for Experiment¶

class t4jbias-backend.tmi.tmi_utils.DescriptorAnalysis¶

Performing a Descriptor Analysis.

get_descriptor_count(headline: str, port: int) → Union[int, list]¶

Retrieves descriptor count for given headline, as well as the descriptor names.

Parameters

  • headline (str) – Headline of the newspaper article.

  • port (int) – Port the CoreNLP server is started on.

Raises

ApiNotStarted – In case the user forgot to start the CoreNLP server.

Returns

Returns the count of descriptors as an integer, as well as the list of descriptors.

Return type

Union[int, list]

class t4jbias-backend.tmi.tmi_utils.Helperfunctions¶

Contains general tmi_utils for performing a TMI Analysis.

corenlp_sentiment_analysis(headline: str, port: int) → int¶

Retrieve the overall sentiment of a sentence via CoreNLP.

Parameters

  • headline (str) – Sentence or headline to be analysed.

  • port (int) – Port on which CoreNLP server is running on.

Raises

ApiNotStarted – Raised if user forgot to start CoreNLP server.

Returns

Returns the score for sentiment ranging from 0(Very negative) to 4 (Very positive).

Return type

int

get_NLU_categories(url_newspaper: str) → dict¶

Classifies newspaper article into predefined categories by Watson NLU.

Parameters

url_newspaper (str) – URL of newspaper article.

Returns

Dict containing any classified category.

Return type

dict

get_NLU_semanticroles(headline_newspaper: str) → dict¶

Retrieves the semantic roles for a newspaper article from Watson NLU.

Parameters

headline_newspaper (str) – Headline for the newspaper to be analysed.

Returns

Retrieved dictionary that contains any semantic roles in the headline.

Return type

dict

get_descriptor_sentiment(descriptor_count: int) → str¶

Determines the sentiment of descriptors solely based on the count of descriptors in the healdine.

Parameters

descriptor_count (int) – Count of descriptors in headline.

Returns

Returns any sentiment from [“Positive”, “Neutral”, “Negative”]

Return type

str

get_image_tags(url: str, port: int) → Union[list, str]¶

Retrieve the image tags, byline and excerpt from an article. This is done by calling a NodeJS Api which utilises the “readibility” package published by Mozilla Firefox. This clears the article’s HTML of any advertisements that might mislead the analysis.

Parameters

  • url (str) – URL of the newspaper article.

  • port (int) – Port that NodeJS API is running on.

Raises

ApiNotStarted – Raised if user forgot to start the NodeJS API.

Returns

Returns the list of image captions retrieved as well as the byline and excerpt.

Return type

Union[list, str, str]

get_political_spectrum(news_outlet: str) → str¶

Web crawler for retrieving political spectrum of a given newspaper.

Parameters

news_outlet (str) – Name of the newspaper.

Returns

String of political direction. Possible returns: [Left, Lean Left, Center, Lean Right, Right]

Return type

str

return_nltk_tree(sentence: str, port: int = 9000) → nltk.tree.Tree¶

Return the NLTK tree of sentence.

Parameters

  • sentence (str) – Sentence to retrieve NLTK tree from.

  • port (int, optional) – Port CoreNLP server is running on, defaults to 9000

Raises

ApiNotStarted – Raised if you user forgot to start the server.

Returns

NLTK tree of sentence.

Return type

Tree
